title_sort: william stansberry to walt whitman, 12 may 1874
title: William Stansberry to Walt Whitman, 12 May 1874
text: MinnesotaWright CoHoward LakeMay 12, 1874Walt WhitmanMy dear friend I received yours dated April 27 was truly glad to hear from you but sorow[sorrow] of you bad health I hop[hope] you will recover soon I think if you was here this clymateclimate would be good for your health the[there] are some coming from different Stats[states] for there[their] health.my friend Whitman I love you when I think of the kindness you shew[showed] to me my heart is swelled with gratitude to you may the lord preserve you and giv[give] you a home in heaven my friend i have bin[been] in a bad stat[state] of health for 10 months I have the dropsy of the heart I am getting better & my family is well mrs[Mrs] Stansberry well wishes to you I will send you my oldes[oldest] girrls[girl's] pictor[picture]. I have not got my on[own] that is fit to send this timeI received the paper with your portrait of the poet Walt Whitman. my wife sais[says] you had better come and stay with us this summer if you remember the black berry . I was in ward d in 65 in armery[Armory] sqSquare you came in every evening I remember of you kissing me if you remember my brother came to see me from West well i must close by saying if we meet no more here that I shall know you in the upper and better world the mind willI have united myself to the Society of friends commonly called Quaker now if you will come t[to] Minnesota. I think this is the healthiest climet[climate] tha[that] I can find if you will be a friend to youI love you as a brotheryours trulyWm Stansberryexcuse my bad writing I am nervesnervous William Stansberry to Walt Whitman, 12 May 1874
